It's become common for crawlers to begin their User-Agent (UA)
strings with a "Mozilla/" identifier, because many sites only
serve their most typical content to such UA values.

See, for example, the list of Bot UAs at Wikipedia:

    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_agent#Bots

No deception is intended by this practice, nor should any be
reasonably expected, as the rest of the UA clearly identifies
who is actually making the HTTP requests.

At least for our purposes in creating the Heritrix crawler --
accurately archiving the web as it is experienced by typical
users -- this behavior is strongly justified. (We also believe
that the many sites which switch their content based on "Mozilla/"
UAs are worth spidering!)

As far as I know, the holders of the Mozilla trademark have
never objected to the use of their mark for this compatibility
purpose, with such use dating back at least 9 years to Internet
Explorer 1.5/2.0 in 1996.

(Further, at least under US trademark case law, there's a
potentially relevant precedent which suggests even mimicking
a competitor's trademark, at the risk of misleading people,
is legal -- if it's the only way to achieve otherwise-lawful
compatibility. [Sega vs. Accolade, 1992] So even if the easygoing
folks over at the Mozilla Foundation wanted third-parties to
stop this long-established practice, they might not have a
legal case. Of course, I am not an IP lawyer and you'd want to
check with your own if this were an area of concern.)

Finally, note that User-Agent is a Heritrix setting that's
overridable on a per-domain basis. If a specific web publisher
requests you crawl them with a different UA, you can accomodate
them, if desired.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA

Marco Baroni wrote:
> Dear Heritrixers,
> 
> I just received the following mail (my user agent string actually has 
> Mozilla/5.0 since that is the default in heritrix...)
> 
> I was wondering:
> 
> 1) Are the concerns of this person justified? My interpretation of the 
> string is that I am asking to be served the page that the server would 
> serve to Mozilla, but I am also clearly identifying my bot as non-Mozilla?
> 
> 2) Did anybody investigate what is the "damage" of using a non-standard ua, 
> such as whatever name our project has?
> 
> Thanks.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Marco
> 
> 
> -------- Original Message --------
> Subject: wacbot UA string
> Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 00:07:21 +0000
> To: baroni@...
> 
> Hi there. I have noticed that your wacbot sends the following user
> agent string:
> 
> Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; wacbot +http://sslmit.unibo.it/~baroni/wacbot)
> 
> Are you aware that this infringes on the Mozilla people's trademark?
> It's also a generally bad thing for the internet to go around
> pretending you're someone else.
> The user agent string you should be sending would preferably look
> something like this:
> 
> wacbot/1.0 (+http://sslmit.unibo.it/~baroni/wacbot)
> 
> I'm not affiliated with Mozilla, but would just like to ask nicely
> that you change it.
> I understand that some sites treat browsers differently if they have
> the word "Mozilla" or "compatible" in the UA, but honestly those
> sites aren't worth spidering anyway, and their numbers are so few
> that a purpose such as yours (linguistics) would be almost unaffected.
> 
>
